ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was really great for introspective assessment. We looked at many different theories and religions but ultimately this coursed helped us think about/reflect on our OWN vision of a life worth living.
take this class. it is so worth it (although i will say, it is what you make out of it - if you want to put your time into it, you will learn so much.
This course taught me to think critically about what constitutes the life worth living in different visions across the spectrum, as well as how to evaluate the core tenets of these visions.

I learned a lot about different traditions of thought in thinking about life and its value. It wasn't heady philosophy and it wasn't religious studies  the perfect middle ground! I was encouraged to ask myself a bunch of important questions about what my own values are, and I discovered a little bit more of my place in the world.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths = one of the biggest strengths of this course was the intimate, small group, seminar design (as opposed to a big lecture). The level of interaction with classmates that this facilitated was great!

Weaknesses = I wish this course would have had a little more background or context on some of the modules. There was a certain level of knowledge assumed (about the history of Buddhism, Judaism, Utilitarianism, etc.) that was not necessarily there. More context for each module would have been nice, even if it add more work.
really thorough and great class, but i wish there was more time to talk about non-western traditions (buddhism, islam, etc).
A strength of this course was certainly the community it provided. Everyone in the class, including the instructor, was incredibly respectful in allowing each of us to share our insights.
I feel like the content was amazing, but there was just a lot to do every week; it became hard to keep up with.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: having the virtual retreat earlier in the semester was great! additionally, our instructor, drew, checked in on us throughout the semester to see how we were doing / whether we felt like we were learning a lot.

I think the retreat, although incredibly unconventional this year, was a tremendous success. There were some minor issues with Zoom breakout rooms early in the semester, but this was quickly cleared up.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I highly recommend this course! It was really great for personal reflection on life, especially at Yale. If you are looking for a class that will be the quintessential "Yale" class, this is it! It has many great components, history, philosophy, religious studies, etc, but ultimately it is up to the student to make the most of the course. If you're willing to "buy-in," this class will be really worth your time!

yes, this is a must-take class at yale. i had strong hesitations/doubts going into this class, mainly because i wasn't sure whether i'd like how in-depth it got and whether i really thought it'd impact my life. that being said, it's really challenged the way i've thought about my vision of a life worth living. if you get into a class, you're in a lucky spot - and if you're in my same shoes reading this comment, give the class the benefit of doubt, open your mind, and just take it. you won't regret it.

I would emphatically recommend this course to any student who is seeking to improve their ability to think critically about the different visions of the life worth living. This class is not meant to provide an answer to what makes a life worth living, its meant to be a tool so that you may find your answer if you so choose.
I would, but maybe as a credit/D or in an otherwise light semester

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar/discussion section that met twice a week, and async lectures.
Also had a weekend retreat Zoom session.
In addition to twice-weekly synchronous seminars, we had readings, recorded lectures, Q&A discussion posts (for the lectures), and weekly self-assessments.
